item.title: The Cambrians Visit Castell Coch in 1912
item.dc:creator: Jack Davies
item.description:
The Cambrian Archaeological Association is a charity dedicated to preserving the history of Wales. They were founded in 1846 and have published the annual “Archaeologia Cambrensis” journal ever since. Many of the early journals are available to read online and they contain some fascinating local history. I discovered a report of the association’s tour of ...

Read more

item.title: Patterns of Castell Coch – Part 3
item.dc:creator: Jack Davies
item.description:
Castell Coch is famous for its spectacular interiors. I’ve decided to illustrate the stencils, murals and patterns that decorate Cardiff’s iconic Gothic Revival landmark. Part 1 and Part 2 of this series have already featured some beautiful designs. Lady Bute’s Bedroom The first patterns I’ve recreated for this instalment are prominent in Lady Bute’s bedroom. ...

Read more

item.title: Castell Coch by Antonio Mortola
item.dc:creator: Jack Davies
item.description:
More than ten years after publishing my first story about a Lego Castell Coch model, I’m excited to share another beautiful creation from a talented Lego builder. Antonio Mortola shared some pictures on social media last year and I recently got in touch to find out more about his work and this amazing model. Antonio’s ...

Read more

item.title: Postcards of Castell Coch – Part 10
item.dc:creator: Jack Davies
item.description:
For Valentine’s Day, I’m sharing this unique panoramic postcard by the famous publisher J Valentine & Sons. J Valentine & Sons was a prominent postcard publisher based in Dundee, Scotland. Founded in 1851 by James Valentine, the company initially focused on photography and printing before venturing into the postcard business in the late 19th century. ...

Read more

item.title: Castell Coch by Mary Traynor
item.dc:creator: Jack Davies
item.description:
I’ve been aware of Mary Traynor’s work for a number of years but only recently picked up a copy of her book about Cardiff. It includes a chapter dedicated to Castell Coch with a couple of paintings by Mary. “Mary Traynor was born in China in 1934 and studied at Goldsmith’s, Birmingham College of Art ...

item.title: Castell Coch by John Warwick Smith
item.dc:creator: Jack Davies
item.description:
I’ve already shared a few illustrations of Castell Coch in the 18th and 19th centuries. This watercolour by John Warwick Smith is another fascinating glimpse of the original castle in its ruined state. From the terrain, it looks like this is the view looking north east. Ivy appears to be growing out of each tower ...

Read more

item.title: Castell Coch in World War II
item.dc:creator: Jack Davies
item.description:
The history of Castell Coch in World War II was, and still is, a bit of a mystery. I spoke to a volunteer in the castle recently and she mentioned that they knew very little about this period of its history. I asked some local residents who know lots about the village and they didn’t ...

Read more

item.title: Cadw Turns 40
item.dc:creator: Jack Davies
item.description:
The 40th anniversary of Cadw has already been covered in the news earlier this month. The BBC article, “From castles to loos – protecting Wales’ history” is well worth a read. Rather than repeat this information, I thought I’d look through my collection for items related to Cadw, share some stories I’ve published about them ...

item.title: Stereoview of Castell Coch
item.dc:creator: Jack Davies
item.description:
I recently found this example of a stereoview featuring Castell Coch. This type of photo is also called a stereographic card or stereogram. A stereoview consists of two photos that, when viewed with a device called a stereoscope, creates a three-dimensional effect. Stereoscopes This antique stereoscope was popular in the 19th century. It’s a “Holmes ...

Read more

item.title: Postcards of Castell Coch – Part 9
item.dc:creator: Jack Davies
item.description:
In this instalment of Postcards of Castell Coch I investigate a 1908 card from a rare Cardiff publisher. Researching this postcard sent me down a rabbit hole investigating the history of a small Cardiff business that was established in 1880 and expanded into the early 1900s. I spent hours looking through decades of adverts in ...

Read more
